I would like to demonstrate the likely falsity of the theory of superposition as it applies to composite entities and thus its implications, I propose the following; The conditions of the Schroedinger’s cat experiment remain exactly the same but for the poison which would be replaced with an acid, the fumes of which would still be lethal to the cat, and a mechanism on the floor of the box which were the cat to lie/fall down, would cause the vile to tip over. When broken, its contents would spill onto the floor of the box and eat through to the outside. In this then, there would be no observer opening the box but rather a chain of interdependent events which would at their end, in effect, be reaching out to the observer after the fact. In other words, the acid leaking from the box would only be possible were the cat dead and only dead. No dead cat, no leaking acid to alarm the observer that he might turn to observe. To illuminate further….that necessary for the Schroedinger version of this scheme is that there be no consequence of events of the cat’s state as either alive or dead or even potentially one or the other. The cat’s state as alive or dead is the end of the sequence of events contained within the box. In my version in which the cat’s state is nested within a line of other deterministic events, those subsequent to the cat’s state cannot be realized materially unless the cat were dead and only dead. The observer would not have looked at all but for the process having in a sense “reached out” to alert him to its presence. If as might be claimed that his observation would cause the wave form to collapse and the condition of the acid dripping to manifest then how could it have been manifest already that it might capture his attention that he might turn to observe it then to cause the wave form to collapse so that it could be dripping which it was in the first place? This makes no sense and defies the same brand or current of logic by which the experiment was initially defined. I would venture that if this cannot be resolved by the proponents of superposition, one then has to question the ability of composite entities to be in superposition, ever. So, we see that here is no wave form here and thus no superposition of the cat. A great deal of physics would fall away in the exposition of such an error with this superposition theory, not merely inviting alternative ontological possibilities but rather demanding their consideration. Silly notions of multi-verses, cyclical universe existing back infinitely and human perception as a component of the means of material existence would all be dispensed with.

The question is how do we go from the super-accurate and deterministic and un-modifiable Schroedinger equation to a random outcome?

The answer is that there is an undescribed physical process at work. There is more than one way to travel faster than light, and in the way that exchanges timelike and spacelike intervals we can have an oscillation which is capable of destructive interference with itself. This is what the SE is normally describing. In the other way to travel faster than light we have orthogonal tachyonic Brownian motion which averages away to nothing at the ensemble level. There is a hint of TBM in that imaginary diffusion term in the SE. The tripartite interaction between TBM, matter and the electromagnetic field can have a classically random outcome such as a cat which is either dead or alive but not both.

This answer is pitched at computer simulation, and TBM is currently the only proposal on the table for making use of a random number generator which does not spoil the wave function because of its orthogonality. We will leave it to the reader to come up with alternative ideas. There might not be any.

"there's no option where the gun powder explodes and the cat doesn't see it explode".......this completely tears apart the thought experiment cuz the gunpowder could explode while the cat naps, thus not seeing the gunpowder explode. there is that option....because the cat is an organic living being, and isn't a constant. the cat's curiosity for the gunpowder bomb is also a variable, causing an unstable imbalance. either the cat ignores the bomb, the cat triggers the bomb, or the cat defuses the bomb....but it's completely dependent on the cat's actions and/or in actions. that means that before observing the results, it's NEVER a true 50/50 split, just an assumed 50/50 split. it is a true 50/50 split on whether the cat is alive or dead when opened, but that's the outcome not how many times that outcome will occur on a large enough test sample.
assuming that there is no prior knowledge of the cat's personality to be disclosed prior to being placed in the bunker with the bomb, probability leans towards the cat surviving. why? because factoring in the cat's curiosity, there are more possibilities that would lead to survival all stemming from the curiosity of the cat. either the cat does nothing but doesn't position itself in a way to survive the bomb, or the cat triggers the bomb are the only 2 possibilities of death. the cat's curiosity defusing the bomb, putting itself in a position to survive the blast, and moving the bomb to increase survival odds are possibilities of survival. a dud bomb being ignored or being accidentally triggered are both possibilities, so the odds are 3/4 survival.
it can be assumed that the cat is 100% alive until proven otherwise, not suspended in a void of simultaneous life and death....and especially a cat where it's literally impossible to map out every single action/inaction the cat will take. the only way to tip the scale back to is to add 2 more variables and that's the health of the cat, and how long the cat is in the bunker without food/water. they can't be counted because they tip the scales to assumed 100% death for sick cats kept for too long.

I hope that most people know that Schrödinger's cat isn't a real theory. It was used as satire to highlight how ridiculous some people's interpretation of the "observer effect" in quantum theory was. Some people believe (and still do) that the act of observing an electron forces it to alter it's behavior from wave-like to particle-like, with the conclusion being that the electron is somehow "conscious" that it is being observed. In reality, observation alters the electron because it is impossible to observe an object without light. It is light that alters the behavior of the electron, not the fact that it is "conscious" of someone observing it.

This is the worst interpretation of schrodingers theory.
The theory was to illustrate the stupidity and absurdity of a observer driven state.
The cats outcome happens regardless of observer, but people have used this theory for their own absurd beliefs.

“In summary, quantum state collapse is not driven just by conscious observers, and "Schrodinger's Cat" was just a teaching tool invented to try to make this fact more obvious by reducing the observer-driven notion to absurdity. Unfortunately, many popular science writers in our day continue to propagate the misconception that a quantum state (and therefore reality itself) is determined by conscious observers. They use this erroneous claim as a springboard into unsubstantial and non-scientific discussions about the nature of reality, consciousness, and even Eastern mysticism. To them, "Schrodinger's Cat" is not an embarrassing indication that their claims are wrong, but proof that the world is as absurd as they claim. Such authors either misunderstand Schrodinger's Cat, or purposely twist it to sell books.”

Source: https://wtamu.edu/~cbaird/sq/mobile/2013/07/30/what-did-schrodingers-cat-experiment-prove/

How about: the other possibility doesn't even exist until you observe it. Thus, viewing the result renders other possibilities null by the acceptance of the reality that the observer (we) just viewed. There is no need for alternate realities, and there is no need for us to have an observer. There is a bunker with a cat and gun powder; there either is or is not an explosion; we view the result; the ultimate reality is that our chances of 50% remain the same. There is one cat, and it is either dead or alive. It is one of us that finds the cat. A singular event in one continuous reality, resulting in one shared experience among observers in one shared and continuous reality. Who makes this quantum decision to allow an equal and opposite possibility for every action and designate it its own reality? This is unnecessary.

The conundrum is made moot with the acceptance of the Universe as "One big thing" with a multiplicity of arbitrarily defined observers and observances.  In a state of "One big thing",  events are never binary, they are either arbitrarily assumed to be binary in awareness or they aren't, and whether or not they are observed alters in no-way the existence of the "One big thing".  Schrodinger' cat as exploded protoplasm in the universe is undifferentiated from Schrodinger's cat as companion to an un-exploded grenade.  The perceived difference is the function of a limited and arbitrary observer placed in a limited and arbitrary space-time.

This version is more of an analogy for superposition. The original thought experiment, as I understand, involved linking a "classical" system to a "quantum" one and exploring the implications of that. Imagine a radioactive atom in a superposition between decaying and not decaying. If the atom decays and emits radiation, a radiation detector will activate and power a motor with a hammer attached to break a vial of poisonous gas; the gas then kills the cat. So in this scenario, because the atom is in superposition, would the cat also be in a superposition of life and death?

The real allure of this thought experiment is the suspension of belief. You don't know what to believe because you're waiting to be told what to believe. Most people subscribe to "Seeing is believing", and are perhaps unknowingly intrigued with this experiment because it allows them to feel and experience raw infinite possibility in its un-limited state. The moment you look into the scene to be told what to think, and therefore what to feel, your reality has not just been conditioned by a party outside of yourself, but it's also been further limited from its previously suspended, unlimited (super) state.

I really wish that Schrodinger's Cat was always explained to be an analogy and not literal. As soon as anything interacts with the live/dead state of the interior of the box, the collapse occurs. There doesn't need to be a consciousness registering the measurement. You just need the interaction (say, with photons) that could be used to deliver the determined results elsewhere (again say, to our eyes) to do it. Whether or not the information is intercepted by something with consciousness is immaterial.

As such, even the interaction with the air particles inside the box would cause the collapse with the cat experiment. But that wasn't the point of the thought experiment. It was to create an analogy in the macro-world that people could understand so they got a clearer idea of what was going on in the subatomic level where quantum mechanics/superpositions become more prevalent.

Actually, there is no “paradox”. The fact that we don’t know something doesn’t make the system “entangled”. Its like your exam score until you see it doesn’t mean it was entangled.

Real entanglement is when in the moment of observation observer project the system on one of the states with different probabilities. So the fact of observation - acting on the system (in different ways) - projects the entangled system.

I believe this is an analogy schrodiner was using to explain one of the basic principles of quantum theory. Please let me explain, as we know in nature an electron will move around the nucleus of an atom at a specific speed and distance from the nucleus. This is the cat. With heisenbergs uncertainty principle we know that for us humans to observe a sub atomic particle we must use a photon(unit) of light, but to use light to observe an electron will excite it so we cannot get its velocity. This is the observer. The electron is only observable in one of its states so we cannot ever get both its velocity and location due to the excitement caused by the light. Thus the analogy of an observer and a cat where the fate of the cat is the dual velocity and position of an electron, and the observer a human trying to observe the cat(electron).

From the point of view of Quantum Physics and the original paper by Schrödinger, what has been told in this video is a complete nonsense. The video tries to deliver a flawed explanation, based on an incorrect understanding of the Copenhagen interpretation of Quantum Mechanics. It also misses the point made by Schrödinger, which was not about ,,simultaneously" living and dead cat, but about an interplay (incoherence) between descriptions of macroscopic and microscopic phenomena. Unfortunately, most popular presentations of the paradox are like that, and even professional physicists tend to believe they are correct. If you want to really understand what the paradox was about, I recommend you to read the paper by Schrödinger, which has been translated into English (for non-German readers).

Ok so here's my interpretation. An example would be Person A observing Person B. Person A sees body parts like hands,legs,face etc. and assumes that that's the only thing which is real. However, the parts are made up of much smaller particles(atoms) which Person A cannot see. Person A's reality is based on what's there. There's body parts in his sight. But let's say there was a creature who can only see atoms(see all things at a micro scale basically). For the creature, the reality is the atoms. Person A would argue with the creature that the creature's reality is wrong but that's not the case. They're both right in their own sense. One just can't see the other reality but they're both realities. Thus it basically means that there might be alternate realities that were not able to see and thus we can't know the “outcom” of it because we have our own reality. Since recent comments seem confused by this, I'll try to help. Keep in mind: I am no professional, just an internet person with a love of science.

The point of Schrödinger's cat is not regarding an actual cat, but quantum particles. Since particles are kind of abstract, a cat is used to help visualise it.

A particle's state exists as a "wave function": a mathematical expression that states how likely the particle is to be in each possible state. It can be said, therefore, that the particle (or cat) is in multiple states at once (i.e. alive and dead). By observing the particle, the wave function collapses to a single outcome and we find out if the cat is alive or dead, but up until this point it was both.

It is important to note that when we say "observe", we don't mean "see", as humans interacting with a reality isn't the factor that shapes the reality. In physics terms, "observe" refers to an interaction with the particle that determines what state it is in. This could be through electromagnetism or interaction with light.

Wow. A lot of misconceptions there.
1) Schrödinger didn't believe in superposition. The Schrödinger's cat thought experiment was his way of disproving it. The idea was to push the superposition theory to its limit to show how absurd it was (how could the cat be alive and dead at the same time). Well, Schrödinger was wrong. We know today that superposition does occur. And it's kind of funny that nowadays people act as if Schrödinger's Cat was a way to explain superposition when it was, in fact, a failed attempt to disprove/ridicule it.
2) What makes the superposition collapse is not the fact that we look. It's the fact that we may look. We don't have to actually look. So the whole experiment is flawed. The superposition would never occur inside the box.
Let me explain a bit more this point. If you do the double slit experiment you get superposition (the photon go through both slits at the same time) but if you put some detector in one slit suddenly the photon go through either the one slit or the other. That's why people say we collapse superposition just by looking. But if you put a detector and never check the result (same as not opening the box) the superposition still doesn't happen. The photon goes through either one slit or the other. You don't have to actually look to force one result or the other.
3) The collapsing itself is not magical (people went mystic when they were told that quantum physics care about a conscious observer) but merely mathematical. The wave function of a single particle is quite simple an support easily superposition but as soon as larger objects are involved the wave function become very complex and the math predicts that a choice has to be made. It's a bit complicated to explain but you can look at it like a dice roll. If you throw one dice, who can tell which value you will get? Maybe one, maybe six, maybe anything in between. But if you throw a billion dice, you know that the result will be pretty close to 3.5 billion. And yet there is nothing magical about the fact that as soon as we throw a huge amount of dice randomness that we can see in single throw seems to disappear completely.

Wrong. Please make a new video explaining Schrodinger's cat and correct the misleading assumption that the cat is actually alive and dead at the same time. That's not true. In short, it has to do with what we have to consider when talking about quantum states. It's not about the cat literally popping from one state to the next. The experiment is actually a criticism of what was demonstrated in this video.

The real "problem" with Schrödinger's cat is not the explained in the video (at least not the important one). It's true, quantum mechanics tells us the observation "creates" the reality (collapses the wave function to a defined state) so "the observer kills the cat" (50% of the times). But, assuming the cat doesn't observes itself (collapses the wave function itself), the interesting thing is:
If we left the bunker closed for two days (for example), when we open the door, we will collapse the wave function, so the cat will be alive or death. But if is alive the cat will be hungry, or if is death the cat will have started to decompose. Not only you are affecting the present to observe a cat alive or dead, you are observing the past, so your observation is affecting the past! That's the real Schrödinger's cat "paradox".

Schrodinger's Cat is a thought experiment often used to help explain what Quantum Mechanics is about.

However, it's easy to take it too literally and think that Quantum mechanics is literally saying "the universe changes based on whether you're looking at it or not." This is not true.

Here is a much, MUCH better example:

You are a blind man. You measure the distance of objects by tossing a tennis ball at them and measuring the time between when the ball leaves your hand and when it returns.

You toss your tennis ball at a medicine ball. The medicine ball, as a result of you tossing the tennis ball at it (and hitting it), rolls a little bit. It is now in a different location because you measured its distance using your method. Your observation changed the medicine ball's state.

Had you not measured the medicine ball's distance, it would be in a different place.

This is basically what you have to do to measure the location of a particle. Particles are too small for you to see. You have to measure them via other means, such as shining an infrared laser at them and measuring the time until the laser returns.

Particles are so light that shining this laser at them WILL ACTUALLY MOVE THEM and change their velocity. This is what is meant by "observation changes a particle's state." There is no magic involved here. The nebulous concept of observing something does not change its state, but the methods you use TO observe it CAN change its state in the subatomic world.

Quantum Mechanics applies exclusively to the subatomic world. Does this make sense now?

I'm not a real expert, but this video still presents the Copenhagen Interpretation of quantum mechanics which makes an unnatural distinction between classical observers and quantum systems (being observed). As I understand, more modern analyses of quantum mechanics can show that the real thing that makes the wave function collapse is decoherence: In essence the fact that the cat interacts with an environment (absorbs photons etc.) and this interaction shifts our observation probabilities to the cat being either dead or alive, with "superpositions" being overwhelmingly unprobable. It has nothing to do with "seeing" the object or even with consciousness: it's just the fact that a macroscopic body (a "bath") interacts with ("is coupled to") the fragile quantum superposition (the radioactive decay that triggers the cyanid capsule, snif). Observers in this approach (I think) are regarded just as macroscopic quantum systems. This approach still has to explain why we "see" those states that turn out to be overwhelmingly probable, and what happens to the other very probable outcome that was not realized in our experiment. And some of these issues are not yet settled even among experts.

I don't understand the necessity/relevance of this thought experiment, or how it really holds any explanatory power, or even what it's meant to explain.

I understand that the cat is in the box, and can only be in one of 2 states. But just because an outside observer doesn't know which state it is in until we look, doesn't mean it is in both. It's in one or the other, we just can't know which one. Nor do I see in any way how it follows that the resolution of those 2 possibilities is contingent on our(or the cats) observation of it.

If you actually blew up a cat with a bomb, in what sense is the cat even able to observe the resolution of the situation? The cat would be vaporized before its biologically limited senses could "perceive" anything.

Most of the explanations of this thought experiment seem to border on granting some sort of magical power to observation. Like a computer game that doesn't render or animate anything out of the player field of view or something. I don't see how that sort of thing is even remotely justified in the real world.

Hoping someone can shed some light on this in a way that makes sense.

This presentation should have mentioned (for better understanding) that the whole reason for the superposition of states is due to a duality often observed at quantum level. At macro level such thing never happens and does't even make sense. The law of indentity prevents something from being A and B at the same time, therefore only one event can be real. But at quantum level things get more bizarre, and a particle CAN be in 2 states or places at the same time. Such duality only exists in the micro world of Quantum Mechanics and could never be observed with the naked eye, of course, but what if... the quantum state of a particle was set to have implications on the macro world we inhabit? How would that duality manifest?
Radioactive decay was initially proposed as a phenomenon used to prompt a manifestation at macro level, since it too is prone to show signs of that duality. If the radioactive decay of a particle had been consummate, it would trigger the opening of a poison flask and kill the cat; if it had not, then the flask would stay closed and the cat be alive. The possible states of the radioactive decay of a particle are able to co-exist in superposition; the life and death of a cat can NOT... When these two (micro and macro) realities are tied together, what's the outcome? Can the flask be open and closed at the same time?
That's the reason for this experiment.

No, no, no... That was not a minute or Schrödinger's point... He was taking quantum superposition and applying it to a scale we can understand.
If you observe something on the quantum scale, you change it. Until observed, things are literally in several places at once (a single particle will go through 2 holes at the same time).
Schrödinger's cat would be in a box, and killed by one of these states, but opening and checking would set off the bomb and kill it. Until observed, the cat was neither dead or alive because the bomb was triggered by one of the two states. He was taking a quantum paradox and bringing it to the macro scale.

The "Schrodinger's Cat" thought experiment was used to emphasize how stupid it was to try and disprove quantum theory by applying it to non-quantum objects. Schrodinger was showing how idiotic it was to argue that a cat should behave the same as, say, an electron and then arguing that it was the quantum physicists that were doing it wrong.

This isn't intended to be taken literally, but it does describe quantum behavior. The intention was to call attention to the stupidity of some of the time's critics.

I thought the purpose of this experiment was to show that observation has no effect on actually reality. Observation only concludes a probability statement, it does not alter the outcome in any way. The cat is not both dead and alive, it is one or the other depending on the unknown mechanical (non-probability based) processes of the TNT or poison contraptions. The issue for quantum mechanics resides at a sub-atomic particle level, such as an electron. Observations do not seem to follow any known process but rather seem to act purely on probability. This philosophical thought is meant to explain the perspective of someone who is trying to observe a particle, and that someone cannot know info regarding the particle until it is stopped. The particle then acts on apparent probability, changing when it is remeasured in a way that cannot be currently explained. Thus, mathematically, the particle is given to exist in more than one way until measured.

A little poem I wrote Schrödinger's Cat:

There once was a cat in a box of lead 
who could have either been alive or dead. 

No one could tell the fate of the cat, 
sealed in there with a glass cyanide vat. 

For in there also, to the cat's dismay,
was a radioactive substance undergoing decay.

And if it happens, a hammer would break the glass, 
and release unto the feline the poisonous gas!

Scientists questioned; people pondered.
"Would the cat be dead" they asked, they wondered,

"or alive and well, and as jumpy as a fox?
We won't really know until we open this box!"

~

Schrodinger's Cat was actually a thought experiment conceived by Schrodinger himself who actually *argued against* quantum theory by illustrating its absurdity quite vividly to the audience. Schrodinger couldn't stand quantum superposition - the supposed state where every possibility (quantum wave function) exists at the same time like the cat being alive and dead inside the box. So he bought up his thought experiment to prove his point and debunk the non-sense of quantum superposition.

However, Schrodinger actually didn't debunk anything, not even by a long shot. His thought experiment was actually nothing more but misleading and quite a distortion to what QM actually tried to point. What Quantum Theory really says is that reality in a quantum sense actually lacks definite existence until observed/measured. This lack of existence encompasses from the smallest (quarts) to atoms that make up the macro world. Only when the quantum world is observed, does it become real and remain in one or the other but not both state. You may as well reject this as nonsense and insist that they are real regardless like Schrodinger's cat, but whether you refuse to believe so or not is completely irrelevant when trying to comprehend the real reality.

It is safe to reject the cat being alive and dead at the same time since literally speaking it is not part of the quantum world for all practical purposes, but the same cannot be said in the quantum world. In the quantum world there is actually no such thing as definite existence independent from observation. Consider the wave-particle duality in the double-slit experiment.

What is the reality of photons? Is it a particle or a wave? Truth is they are both. Yet their reality is far stranger. When the photons are not measured in a double-slit, they behave as a wave and later form an interference pattern. In this reality the photons are a wave. Yet, put a measuring device in and you will see a different reality. Instead of behaving as waves, they actually behave as solid billiard balls - forming only two parallel lines with no interference pattern. Wait, how can a photon be a particle or a wave? Welcome to the real schrodinger's cat story. What really happened was that the photons were actually behaving as particles and waves at the same time. That is because the quantum superposition state forbids them from being one or the other due to the lack of observation/consciousness. They actually don't exist in a definite sense, but rather exist in a probable wave-like (half/half) sense just like Schrodinger's cat. This says a lot about reality

If reality lacks definite existence until it has been observed consciously or at least measured, then that would imply that everything we see in this world was actually created by observation. If this is true, then what or who is this observer exactly that started everything in the first place? This is a mystery that haunts even the most famous quantum physicists like Richard Feyman.

Unless, of course, you're a believer in the multiverse, which quantum mechanics actually does not support empirically.

Our knowledge does not alter or create the facts. The facts are determined if there is an observer, which proves that they are also determined if there is no observer. Saying otherwise is obviously wrong.

I'll try my best to explain this. This whole experiment is an analogy to Quantum physics. The cat represents quantum particles which have been proven by The Double Slit Experiment to change the outcome of their behavior when they are observed.

Henceforth there are 2 possible explanations, either of which would tremendously change philosophy if proven right:

This is a really bad explanation. 

Or rather, its only half of it. The experiment has to be connected, at some level, to a quantum mechanical system that is truly random. 
If the cat is just in a bunker with some gunpowder, you can easily predict the outcome. No explosion.

The gunpowders ignition must be connected to something quantum mechanical, like the radioactive decay of an atom, something that is fundamentally totally random. This must be what triggers, or doesn't trigger, the gunpowder.

The idea isn't that things don't happen until we see them. That is not what the Schrodinger's Cat thought experiment is suggesting.

The idea is that a quantum mechanical system, when connected to a normal scale, physical system, seems to produce 2 realities, that cannot be predicted until the experiment is observed.

what you're stating here just isn't very good science. it's human misconception. sorry, but "reality" is not a "Weeping angel" (doctor who reference). What happens to the cat, whether the gun powder or gas kills it-----is not dependent AT ALL on our, or other particles OBSERVANCE of the result of said experiment. It happens, or it doesn't. There is no super-position where it is both dead & alive until it is observed to be only one instance or the other. We don't KNOW which it is, and we know it can only be one, but our observance of it doesn't CAUSE or NEGATE either of the possibilities...or CAUSE it to occur-----unless you state that our scientific experiment is what killed the cat, rather than our curiosity of the result of said experiment. It was the act of putting the cat in the position to possibly die that killed it. whether we look or not, doesn't change the resulting outcome, or force it to occur from an otherwise superposition or multi-state.

The many worlds interpretation (MWI) is quite elegant is explaining the wavefunction collapse.  In fact, it says it doesn't collapse at all. The probability density is continuous before and after observation if it spans the many worlds (in half the worlds, the cat dies, in the other half, it lives).  Therefore, the probability density doesn't collapse to a sharp spike around (cat lives) or (cat dies) after observation, because the cat DID live in 50% of the cases (of the worlds) and DID die in 50% of the other cases (the other worlds).

What's inelegant about it is that it substitute an unapproachable problem (wavefunction collapse) with another (can't interact with the other worlds).  Therefore, MWI is more mathematically satisfying, but physically it's the same dead-end

You're missing an element of the experiment; it's about whether or not a radioactive sample would remain in a stationary state until observed, as it would if you follow the Uncertainty Principle espoused by Verner Heisenberg of the Copenhagen school of quantum mechanics.  Schrodinger disputes this argument by theoretically placing the radioactive sample in a closed environment with a cat and a Geiger counter set up to trigger the release of poison gas if the sample decays.  If Team Copenhagen is right, kitty should be just fine.  That is Schrodinger's challenge; would you put kitty in that box?  You monster.

As interesting as it is, there is a little known fact about this thought experiment. Schrodinger did not intend for it to be interpreted this way. When the thought experiment was proposed, it was to show that our current understanding of Quantum mechanics is flawed, as it forces us to say that the cat is in a superposition when we know, as rational beings, it is either dead or alive. The experiment was not intended to illustrate a concept, but to illustrate a flaw in our understanding of the universe.

I always laugh at those who insult others for believing or not believing in a certain theory. Believing - or not believing - this does not make one stupid. Though it does probably make the person who is accusing someone of being stupid, stupid. Please note the word "probably" in the previous sentence. Those of truly great intellect are less likely, statistically speaking, to insult another person's intelligence. For two reasons: first those of truly great intellect know how little they know (whereas most others don't even know what they don't know), and second they are actually more likely to underestimate their own intelligence. I believe it is Vsauce who has a great video discussing this phenomena.  

But the greatest reason I laugh when I see people say "you must be a great mind then that of Einstein, and other great mind connected to these theories" is because so many times in science have our "theories" been proven wrong. It is an unbelievable amount. And it is the objective of any scientist out there to question theories. To question what it is that we really know, and what we simply have gotten wrong. Veritsium has a good video on why we shouldn't try to prove ourselves right but rather prove ourselves wrong. However most people do the exact opposite. It is usually these people who criticize others. If you do this though, you truly know little of science. By the way if we didn't question "theories" we would think the sun revolves around the earth, we probably wouldn't know anything about medicine, bacteria, diseases, etc. We would think the smallest object in the world is the atom, which can't be split (if we even realized its existence in the first place), and we would probably be even as ignorant to think that feelings come from the heart rather then the brain.

Actually this is not quite correct Henry, the cat is not in a superposition unless it is PUT in a superposition via some quantum process (you said that it just is, which is wrong), otherwise your lack of knowledge would place it in a statistical state or dead OR alive and not dead AND alive.

But say it IS in a superposition, then it would have to be extremely entangled with all of its degrees of freedom, and losing even one (to the environment, with a stray photon say) would kill the entanglement and give again a dead OR alive state which is purely classical and paradox-free.

But #2, even if it was Schrodinger's electron-spin, and not Schrodinger's cat, a tiny degree of freedom that you know everything about and is not macroscopic as a cat (and you keep it seperate from all interactions with the environment when in the box), there's a neat way around the "collape" that does not have any "collapse" or "multiverse" or "observer" in it, decoherence and quantum darwinism (http://arxiv.org/abs/0903.5082) which I think should be mentioned as a more acceptable and non interpertation-dependant solution to this "problem".

Schrödinger's cat is basically Schrödinger pointing out the flaws of the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics.

According to the Copenhagen interpretation, subatomic particles may exist in all potential states until observed. Schrondinger pointed out this was ridiculous by proposing the following scenario (copied from Wikipedia; I'm not THAT bored):

"A cat, a flask of poison, and a radioactive source are placed in a sealed box.

If an internal monitor detects radioactivity (i.e. a single atom decaying), the flask is shattered, releasing the poison that kills the cat. The Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics implies that after a while, the cat is simultaneously alive and dead. Yet, when one looks in the box, one sees the cat either alive or dead, not both alive and dead. This poses the question of when exactly quantum superposition ends and reality collapses into one possibility or the other."

The point is that the cat CAN'T be alive and dead, regardless of outside observation.

“[It] prevents us from so naively accepting as valid a "blurred model" for representing reality. In itself, this would not embody anything unclear or contradictory.” - Erwin Schrödinger [translated, obviously].

This is heavily metaphoric in quantum theory. By observing an entangled quanta you change the state (weight, direction, speed) of the opposing quanta no matter the distance. But in Schrodinger's Cat. it was saying that until you know they outcome it can be one or the other, but not neither. The cat is in a "superstate". Until someone KNOWS the outcome there is no outcome. So in THEORY the cat is both dead and alive. Only by the act of observing it, is it forced to be one or the other. If you buy a lottery ticket and don't scratch it. It is both a winner and a loser until you find out/rule out on of the other with the act of observing/scratching it. Then it becomes either a winner or a losing ticket. But before you looked at it, it was not a winner or a loser. It was in a superstate.

This creates a paradox in which the observer in the experiment (who for science's sake is supposed to remain 100% objective) is irrevocably subjective, because of our limited "scope" of reality. Therefore, it is impossible for us to be truly scientific in this scenario, or any scenario, because our results will always contain the biasedness of our own existence and limited subjective observation. It seems to me that people fail to understand one thing about Schrödinger's Cat:
It is not supposed to show, that a cat is both dead and alive, until someone checks it. It is (originally) supposed to tell quantum physicists: "You are all idiots" (sorry)
It takes quantum rule (that particles like photons are at all places of the universe at the same time, until someone checks where they are), and makes an absurd example of a cat that is both alive and dead, just because no one saw it die.

Let's say the cat was in the box and someone asks you "is the cat alive or dead" and you say "It's dead". Then after you open the box you find out that the cat was dead. Well if you think about it it's really simple. But... What if maybe the cat was alive and at the time you said "it was dead" it died?. Then somehow let's say you create a time machine and went back to time and said " the cat is alive". And when you open the box It was alive. How did that happen?. Our choices in the future influence the past.

Therefore his state of right or wrong is unknown. Not both. Similarly, the cat's state of alive or dead is unknown. Not both dead AND alive.

Schrodinger wanted to show that the standard interpretation of collapse of the wave function was wrong: he and Einstein were on one side of the debate and Bohr and Heisenberg (?) were on the other side. 

Schrodinger's cat thought experiment was meant to argue against the AND in the quantum superpositions (where something is x, or y, or x AND y) and that such a superposition continues until an observation is made.  Since the radioactive atom (not mentioned in this bad video) should be in a superposition of being both not decayed AND decayed, the cat should be in a superposition of being both alive AND dead.  But clearly, the cat is either alive OR dead throughout, not alive AND dead, so something is wrong with the standard interpretation. 

In short, his thought experiment was meant to bring the microscopic quantum world up to the macroscopic, observable world, and show that we don't observe what we should observe if the standard interpretation were correct.

While accurate to many of the arguments that have stemmed from Schrodinger's Cat, this video fails to note the point of that conversation between Einstein and Schrodinger to which it alluded. Einstein was complimenting Schrodinger on his idea for a thought experiment that showed just how ridiculous the concept of observation causing collapse was. The idea that maybe nothing collapses at all was developed by Everett later. Omnes called the debate between Everett and conventional collapse-theories a "chasm". But Schrodinger's Cat is a ridiculous example meant only to eliminate a view that nobody really had anyway.

Like most of the comments I see here, I too was head fucked by this when I first encountered it years and years ago. But just to clear a few things up.
It's just a thought experiment, that's all. Nothing to do with real cats, nor conscious observers. An observer can just be another particle, this is the reason quantum computing is such a hard problem. You need to keep the quantum computer bits completely isolated in superposition, yet also able to read their output.
So we don't ever see superposition phenomena in our lives. But don't let this message dampen your wonder, because this is still the way reality works on a deep level, and it's fucking crazy!

It's was all a joke anyway. A way of visualising how crazy the standard model of Quantum Physics seems. The way a particle could be considered to be in both states (superposition) until an observer takes a measurement and looks.  And this act of observation changing the outcome has been observed in the double slit experiment. Let Photons "choose" which slit to pass though and it will create an interference pattern because the photon will act as a wave and cancel itself out in some areas, it could be said to be passing through both slits. However, start to observe which slit the photons pass through and it acts as a particle and the interference pattern will disappear. The act of observation alters reality. Since all of time, the past, present, and future all exist simultaneously, the cat being either dead or alive already exists, whether or not we look. So the cat does not really have a 50/50 chance of death at all, it has a 100% chance of either life or death depending on extraneous factors. In quantum mechanics, there seems to be no way to determine the exact position of any subatomic particle at any given time, but this has been interpreted by scientists that the quantum world in probabilistic, and NEVER has any direct causal factors that directly control anything, but a little while later, Einstein discovered quantum entanglement. This phenomenon is completely causal in the quantum world, even if there is currently no mathematical model to explain it, and every particle in the universe could be entangled with any other particle in the universe, but since we can't see every particle in the universe, it is just easier to interpret the evidence we CAN see as probabilistic.

The idea that the observer can influence the observed, by simply observing I think is just silly and not really doing what we think it's doing and here's why I think that : The process by which you observe, is a neurological one. Your brain has to receive the information first. Remember that you always live in the past, so to speak.. because you never get instant updates on what's happening. So when you are observing something, you are actually way later with your analysis and the event has already happened. By contrast, if you go to the quantum level and mix the observer and the observed, so that you can say the observer influences the observed by observing it, then he is not an observer anymore, by definition. Even if something does happen where as the "observer" would influence the observed, it would be because of the quantum power of the observer since the observer and the observed live in the same system. For instance : imagine a mirror but not just any mirror. This mirror can show you the actual particles that float in your brain so that they generate thought. Now imagine you look into that mirror. You're observing it and get information for your next behavior, but as you do, the particles change and you get new information about it and so on and on. It is because you are not an observer. For it is by definition, that an observer must NOT interact with the observed environment. In fact, an observer, by this definition could not even exist since you need access to the observed environment in order to observe it. And if you have that access, it is because you live in an environment where the observed environment is possible, thus becoming 1 environment.

WOW, it really is sad... but the comments show how many people totally miss the REAL science behind this thought experiment and think it is just human arrogance that created the quantum entanglement "theory".
    Schrodinger is not trying to say things don't happen unless we see them happen like most people gathered, that is only the quantum entanglement "theory". But analogies are very misleading and unclear to those that don't know what the base of the analogy is. You need to realize Schrodinger is basing this analogy on how at the quantum level, electrons change their position when observed so we say they are in a superposition. So in other words when we try to pinpoint an electron in it's path around the atom it is everywhere we look when we look there, but not everywhere at once necessarily because we can still pinpoint it. This proven nature of electrons was the source of the quantum entanglement theory which is more of what people gathered than the actual science behind this thought experiment.

To the commenters here exasperated:  you've missed the point somewhat.  Firstly, you need to recognize that this is trying to make an analogy of a quantum state and any time you use an analogy to describe something, you lose accuracy.  Secondly, Schrödinger used this analogy to point out how ridiculous it is rather than have some grand idea.

 However, the overall point that observation of an experiment at the quantum level changes the experiment so you can only really deal in probabilities (the Copenhagen interpretation) seems to hold true.

The video doesn't go into an important detail that Schrodinger posed in his original thought experiment. His theoretical case was that there was a cat sealed in a room with a Geiger counter, and only one atom decaying is enough to trigger the counter, and subsequently kill the cat. The paradox is, if particles behave in a superstate until you observe them, what happens to the cat? The cat's fate would be directly related to a single particle either decaying or not, with an equal chance of both.

Hmm. I think the phrase "reality collapses" is misleading. I'm no expert, far from it, but from what I do know, it's not the act of observing that makes "reality collapse," it's the fact that an isolated quantum system is interacting with another, much larger, quantum system (us observing it). That is, the original system affects the larger system in some way; we become "entangled" with that system.

There is indeed a thing such as superposition. You can see it in a lake if you throw a couple of rocks in a lake. The waves add up. Quantum mechanics deals with wave functions which, being waves, can add up. This concept of superposition of particles can be very foreign, and I don't blame anybody for being skeptical, but the fact is that it happens. A famous example is the double slit experiment.

The point is that you don't know whether it's dead or alive before you check it, and that, according to quantum mechanics, it can be in a "superposition" of both states at the same time. The second you check if it's dead or alive, you are destroying this superposition by interfering with the system. And it was a "thought" experiment. In Descartes view, the only thing we can be certain exists is our own mind, since as long as we can think "I exist," there must be a self doing the thinking, and thinking happens in the mind. So all Descartes is absolutely SURE of is that he exists, and that he is a thinking thing. 

The rest of Descartes ontology (what exists) is built up on this immutable fact, but has lesser and lesser degrees of certainty the higher up he gets.

I find Schrodinger's cat to be a theory to explain what would happen in quantum mechanics in the event that you were to observe the exact same action (outside of time) over and over again. If you were to flip a coin, see the result and look back in time (but not change it in anyway), the coin will always land on the same side because predetermined physics have made it so; whereas with quantum mechanics, an input outside of time causes the result to alter.
This is what I understand it to mean.

I believe the reasoning behind this is that when looking at quantum physics (or not looking, as it turns out) both possibilities of an electron behaving as a particle or as an E-M wave happen simultaneously, whereas when we observe the particle we force the electron to 'make up it's mind' and do one or the other.
It's an incredibly bizarre and so far unexplainable phenomenon.

This is an extension of quantum theory. In the quantum world, things do happen as probability, and observation does collapse the probability. For example, a single photon can pass through two holes at exactly the same time, but when you set up equipment to measure which hole it passes through, it only passes through one hole. Observation collapses the outcomes into one outcome. This is pulling quantum theory into the full sized world. It is only a thought experiment though.

I just don't understand the rationale of considering something to be in a superposition of its potential outcomes just because its true outcome is unknown. At least for things that are macroscopic.

On the contrary, an experiment, called "The Double Slit Experiment," has been done with light particles. watch?v=WAvqTOOyWGg.  It states that each photon acts like a wave and seems to go through both slits at the same time when not observed.  When it is observed, then the photon acts like a particle and only goes through one of the slits.  Human perception changed how the photons act.  This led to the "Many Worlds" theory and the belief of multiple universes.

Our observation of the cat determines whether it is dead or alive because we simply do not know if it is dead or alive prior to opening the box.  One person may say that the cat is alive, and another may say that the cat is dead, and they could both be right.  It is only after opening the box that they find out the status of the cat. Think of all the religions, they could all be right about god's role or gods' roles in the creation of the universe.  But in this case, we may never know the truth.

Let me just explain that this thought experiment was actually Shrodinger basically saying that the Copenhagen Interpretation of quantum physics (that in certain situations light can be both a particle and energy) sounded completely ridiculous. Reductio ad absurdum - "Reduction to absurdity." Or to copy from Wikipedia: "To demonstrate that a statement is false by showing that a false, untenable, or absurd result follows from its acceptance."

So this is pretty much like a coin thrown in the air, right?

While it's in the air, it's both heads and tails, it's the floor "interacting" with the coin which forces the coin to be either heads or tails. If there was no floor, nothing would "force nature's decision", and the coin would be in a "superposition" - being both heads AND tails.

Okay, I'll try and explain this.
Imagine that instead of seeing the gunpowder explode, the cat feels the explosion/impact wave. It's possible for the cat to feel the explosion resulting in it's death, It's also possible for the cat NOT to feel the explosion and survive.. Since there's a 50/50 chance of both happening, the Universe makes it so that BOTH are true, until we open the shaft and check. When we check, only one can be true, because we force the Universe to make a choice.

Atoms and smaller things can exist at more than one state because each particle can be independently chaotic unless you follow a strict checklist. A cat is truly alive OR dead, but the cat's atoms provide so much to measure that the cat itself is not in some obscure state. The chance of any given particle to randomly flux is measurable, but to keep track of every quanta in the cat is not enough to support a superposition.

Here, this will make it simpler to understand. This weird form of logic that says something exists in two ways(quantum state) until measured was at one time baffling early quantum physicists who thought these types of logic should apply like the cat in the thought experiment. Schrodinger was demonstrating that even if these types of logic exist at all, it exists at such a small level that the overall macroscopic state of trillions of cells in the cat all its atoms is unnoticeable, so irrelevent.

Pt. 2 In order to observe a particle we must bounce photons off of it. This changes the particles position and momentum. Only so much about a particles position and momentum can be known at one time (heisenbergs uncertainty principle). Suppose 2 particles collide one particle is tracked for momentum, the other for position. Through calculation you should be able to find the position and momentum of both. However this would violate the principle, so by observing one particle it affects the other.

I know the idea sounds counterintuitive, but it all comes down to heisenbergs uncertainty principle that states that basically states there is a limit on how much we can know about the universe around us. Two particles interact and they become entagled sharing the same wave function. By observing the particle the shared wave functions collapse both particles reach a different quantum state. The cat is just an example of how objects on a quantum scale can affect objects on a classical scale.

The quantum mechanical behaviour that involves superosition of states is a property of SMALL objects.

LARGE objects (grains of sand, bombs, cats, people, planets) behave classically - a large scale emergence of QM behaviour. An "observer" doesn't have to be a person, or "a God". It can also be a kitten, a bomb, or a rock - i.e. anything classical.

The cat is not in a superposition of states, any more than we are, or the bomb. Only the particle that triggers it.

It was a critique of a particular aspect of quantum mechanics meant to provoke discussion about the issues inherent within the Copenhagen interpretation's answer to the questions brought up in the EPR article by making the thing in superposition an observer itself. It isn't an explanation, it's a critique and a question.

The only application of this thought experiment, from the beginning, was for Schrödinger to illustrate why he felt it was stupid for people to believe the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum entanglement. Under that interpretation the idea that we're measuring something previously undefined causes it to decide to be one way or the other at the time we measure it. Schrödinger pointed out that under that logic a cat in an uncertain position is both dead and alive, which is clearly nonsense.
But how can you know the answer if you don't see it? Isn't that faith, then, and not science?

The coin is an imperfect analogy because with a coin we do know before hand that it is either heads or tails. The uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics tells us that it is literally impossible to know both a particles position and velocity at the same time, so we have to think of particles in terms of wave functions. When we observe a particle however we are interacting with it in a way that collapses the wave function. Until we observe the particle is actually in many states at once.

For that matter, what's the difference between "superposition of states" and just "no information"?

In the original posing of the Schrodinger's cat problem, the gunpowder/poison gas was triggered by the radioactive decay of a particle, the probability of which is governed by quantum mechanics. Not just "unstable gunpowder". It is a way of tying the superposition of quantum states to a macroscopic system. Depending on your interpretation of QM, since the triggering particle is a superposition of all possible states until an observation collapses it to a single state (decayed or not),

It's not a paradox, it's a problem.  In Quantum Physics, particles are not constantly in one state.  eg: electrons have spin, and that spin is measurable.  Let's say an electron can spin left or right.  When you measure spin, it will be either left or right, with 50% probability, but it is in superposition until it is observed. That's basically the point they were making with the "Schrödinger's cat" thought experiment, that reality ought to be reality, whether or not we can see it. The problem is there are cases when particles behave as if they're both "dead" and "alive" at the same time, if you will, until they're observed. One of the questions this raises is how large of an object can we suspend in multiple states? Hence the cat, demonstrating the absurdity of it all when we blow it up to our large-scale universe.

Perhaps I'm straying off a bit on this one but we're the reason why the cat is alive or dead. The fact that we opened the hatch allows us to determine the cat's fate. When the word 'determine' comes to mine we think it's what we cause to happen, in actuality it's used in a way of where we come to think.

Since we determined the cat's fate, we can therefore say that the cat is dead or alive. This, however, cannot be applied to the events before that, which gives us Schrodinger's Cat.

When we, the observers, open up the hatch to see whether the cat is truly alive or not we can only say -- or think rather -- that the cat is one of the two: dead or alive. Now, at this point we're really just labeling the situation that the cat is present in.

When the cat is actually in the bunker we have no label to attach to cat in its present situation, whatever it may be. Therefore, the cat is in a state of being dead and alive, and in a state of being neither dead nor alive.

I'm rather sure it makes more sense to put this way: Say the cat is in a state or it being dead or alive. We, the observers, cannot know whether the cat is one or the other due to not observing. Now, a bit of some side info. Humans give terms to expressions, objects, and concepts to better understand our environment. Say there's a pot. Now, in reality, it isn't a pot -- it's just an object that we've given a name to.

Now, apply this to whether the cat is dead or not.

The cat is actually more like a metaphor for a classic Newtonian view of the universe, and the gunpowder is a metaphor for the new quantum view. Quantum theory states that atoms are so small, you can't observe them without changing what they are. Therefore, an unobserved quantum particle is in a state of superposition, or being in all possible states at once. That means that the gunpowder is both exploded and intact, but a cat can't be alive and dead. So which reality actually exists for the cat

The whole cat thing is a metaphor for tiny particles in quantum physics. At a certain level things don't exist in the physical sense but only as wave functions (a superposition of several different possible "places"). Schrödinger eq. tells us where and when we can find it. But this wave function collapses when we observe it. In simplified terms, it is the reduction of the physical possibilities into a single possibility as seen by an observer.
Who cares if it is not explained? Either it happened or it didn't.

The cat is an analogy for tiny particles in quantum physics, where a particle under certain conditions will occupy all possible states (cat is alive and dead at the same time) until observed (looking in the box). Said particle will behave in all possible ways as well until it is observed, which is when it "forces a reality" and behaves in only one of its possible states. Quantum physics is very counter-intuitive and hard to understand/explain in 500 characters.

that it genuinely went through both. If you now put a detector in front of one of the slits to determine exactly which slit the electron went through, the interference pattern on the screen disappears and you see exactly what you'd classically expect of particles hitting a screen.

What you see on the screen is individual hits, individual electrons arriving, exactly like particles. If you let this carry on for a long time, the pattern that is built up is the same pattern you get in the wave version (with light). This means that the electron, represented by its wavefunction, is passing through both slits at the same time before arriving at one clearly defined point on the screen. The point here is that it's not that we don't know which slit the electron went through but

The cat was supposed to make it easier to visualise the situation. Another example of the same phenomenon is that of particle diffraction. I assume you're familiar with Thomas Young's experiment with passing light through a pair of slits to show it behaves as a wave? Exactly the same thing can be done with particles: fire a beam of, say electrons at a screen with two slits in it. Now turn down the 'brightness' of the source until only one electron at a time is being sent through.

Schrodinger's cat is a reductio ad absurdum. This means that it was made to prove one argument (in this case, the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics) wrong.

The end result of a cat being "dead AND alive" is absurd, and that is the entire point. 

It means that not all occurrences are subjective to observation. This was the point of Einstein, Poldosky and Rosen, whom Schrodinger sought to exemplify through this thought experiment. It was not to entertain the idea of dead&alive cats

The 50/50 chance is based on a presumable infinity of outcomes ultimately collapsing into 1 outcome. However, if the experiment were conducted only 3 times and still collapsing into 1 consequence then the probability becomes 1/3. Could the cat only be injured?

this experiment uses "observer" very loosely.

but on the fundamental particle scale, to "observe" means to shoot photons at the experiment, in order to detect the position of particles, this is why the act of detecting alters the experiment.

another way to proove this is the Half-Life of a unstable element.

like Uranium, a 1 kilogram piece of Uranium has an exact half-life, you can know exactly the time it takes for half of this thing to radiate away, however, it is is IMPOSSIBLE, to determine when 1 atom of Uranium will undergo nuclear fission, it is truely random, it can take 5 seconds, or 5 thousand years.

the beauty is that the more atoms you bring together, the less probabilistic and the more deterministic it becomes.

that's the point of the experiment, on the large scale, our world seems to work on the base of determinism, cause and efect.

on the quantum scale, our world is based on probabilities, probabilities wich cancel out the more particles come together to form a stable sistem, or body.

so in a way, maybe nature is probabilistic and deterministic at the same time.
i see what you did there

"observation" in particle physics means shooting a photon at a particle, detecting it, and therefore changing it.

so observing the cat is not like detecting a particle.

this experiment is purely a thought experiment, of course the cat either dies or lives.

but on the quantum scale things are not like that , particle do behave like waves, it's this behavious that is prooven by the double slit experiment.

the confusion arises from the word "observing" being used instead of "detecting" .

if you think of this experiment purely on the level of a cat in a box, then it seems , and is logical, only 1 thing happens.

but on a quantum scale, it is very very complex, on the quantum scale in order to determine the postion of a particle, you must shoot a photon at it, changing it's momentum, and therefore screwing up it's trajectory.

in a way, yes, two paralel universes are created by this.

because on the quantum scale, this probability wave can behave like a real-life wave.

a single photon can behave like a wave, pass through 2 slits, interfere with itself, and land on a RANDOM position on the wall, if the photon was an iron ball, this would be impossible.

however, the double slit experiment has been done with C60 molecules, showing that entire molecules can behave like waves, but the wave-lenght is much smaller because of overlapping.

the probability wave simply shows our inability to find out unless we interfere with the particle, it's the basic uncertainty principle, that in order to find out the position of a particle, you must interact with it, and therefore change it's path , in a way, changing the position the particle wanted to take before you messed with it.

unlike the cat, the particle can behave like a wave , even an actual wave, like the double slit experiment shows.

well, at the scale of the cat, only 1 thing truely happens, you can never know wich happened unless you look, but that doesn't mean both happen , it means you need to look in order to find out, and if you don't look, you simply cannot say wich happens.

by analogy, if you do not interact with a fundamental particle, you cannot claim where it is, but it doesn't mean it's everywhere at once does it? this is what the probability wave describes, but the probability wave itself is not physical.

My understanding is that Schrodinger disagreed with the interpretation of "existence in superposition" of quantum particles, and used the cat thought experiment as a reductio ad absurdam: a quantum particle's state determined whether the poison was released/gunpowder exploded. Since the quantum particle was in two simultaneous states (superposed), then the cat had to be in two states. Absurd - and thus, for Schrodinger, superposition was not a sufficiently accurate explanation.

That's not how it works.

Say you flip a coin, and instantly cover it up as soon as it lands. You don't know whether to coin is heads or tails until you uncover it, and so until then it is heads or tails at the same time - a superposition.

Basically, it means that a thing which can normally exist in only two states - eg an electron spinning upwards or downwards can exist in either (and so both!) states at the same time, until you observe it and so stop being uncertain.

Schrodinger's Cat was not intended as an explanation of the Copenhagen interpretation, as you suggest here; it was intended as a criticism of the Copenhagen interpretation. Schrodinger constructed this thought experiment to show that the Copenhagen interpretation led to an absurd scenario in which the cat was simultaneously alive and dead, and he argued that this implied that the Copenhagen interpretation was wrong.

The problem isn't observation, it's the possibilities of something happening, and parallel universes.  Say we had 500 different colored marbles, and we were to pick one.  500 parallel universes are theoretically "created" which predict the outcomes of pulling a marble out.  

If the bomb blows up near the cat it's impossible to tell if it's dead or alive.  Two parallel universes are "created" - one with the cat dead and the other alive.  It's observation that causes which universe is resulted.

We aren't special.  The whole idea is parallel universes, not observation.  If you detonate a bomb in a soundproof bunker with a cat, it's impossible to know whether it's dead or alive.  The possibilities creates two parallel universes.

Also, no one is observing anything - the idea of the experiment is a metaphor.  It implies that the Big Bang could have several outcomes, such as: the process goes normal, or some law of physics breaks and ends up destroying everything, etc etc.

The cat is already alive or dead before Schrodinger opens the bunker. There seems to be a lot of confusion about what an observation is. By "observation" we mean "measurement" which requires the system in question to interact with another system. Since the cat is made of MANY particles interacting, everything is already set.

What people here in the comments are missing is that this effect is not just the old philosphical problems of 'what is reality?' but is specific to our best description of the tiny world. Things to bear in mind:

1. The tiny world does not necessarily behave like the large world and so is hard to describe in terms of our intuition. See Wave-Particle Duality and Double-Slit Experiment.

2. You can't measure something small without significantly changing it. See Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle.

If it helps - a lot of Einstein's work (and many others) took on the challenge of "relativity", which is basically the same thing appearing differently to different perspectives. This video showed a distinction between reality (something no living thing can "observe"), and the different perspectives of the cat and the observer. It's just trying to show how, when someone can't see the outcome of a random, two-option situation, it so happens that both outcomes are "true" until observed.

The way I interpret this is not the implications of the cat being alive or dead - it's the implications of the state of superposition. It's a metaphor, folks. There are particles that seem to behave differently when observed and when not observed - a mystery that, to my understanding, still baffles science. I see Schrodinger's cat as a simplification of this paradox - separate realities, existing in separate perspectives, collapsing together when the observations are combined.

First off, this only applies to quantum particles. Cats, people, etc. do not exist in superposition since they do not exist in the way quantum particles do.

If Schrodinger's Cat could exist in reality, the simple act of adding a measuring device inside the box would still collapse the wave function, except we wouldn't notice that. This thought experiment was originally proposed by Schrödinger as an objection to the Copenhagen interpretation of QM. According to this interpretation of QM (which is the most widespread one) the state of a QM system is in a superposition of basic states (which yield a measurement when measured), when measuring the system it will collapse to only one of these basic states.
The idea of Schrödingers cat is that when the cause for the cat's death is in a superposition, so must also the cat be.

This is a mass misconception. Superposition is not when something is in both states. The whole point of superposition is that it's not in neither state, not in both states, and is not in one of the states, it's something *different* - it's actually a linear combination of the two vectorstates. Saying that the cat is both dead and alive is incorrect.

Thank you for your answer, much appreciated. So to understand this right and back to basics; in quantum physics, only when observed does this electron/particle change into a form/result? 

How does an observation actually interact with an already occurred event?

You can set up the experiment such that the grenade explodes if one particle changes energy states, which is likely 50% of the time. That particle, by quantum superposition, is 50% in one energy state and 50% in another at the same time. But the grenade can't go off 50% and not go off 50% at the same time. There is a line between that one atom and the grenade where the superposition theory breaks down.

The way this video explains it makes it seem that way. The idea actually has to do with the uncertainty principle in quantum physics, which states that quantum particles such as electrons are in all possible energy states at the same time, and only when measured does it occupy one single quantum state. Schrodinger's experiment highlights the problem with this theory, unlike the grenade particle having a 50% chance of being in any energy state, the cat cannot be 50% alive and 50% dead.

The answer is simple.  Cats are big, heavy things.  And as big, heavy things, they do not run on probabilities the way quantum particles do.  (well, they do, but the odds are like infinity:1 against anything special happening.)  The cat problem has been misunderstood for decades now.  It's not trying to say that we live in a universe governed by probability at a large scale, but rather, that we don't.  That was the point Schrodinger was trying to make.

Schrodinger’s cat is an allegory to explain some of the “weird” things that happen in quantum mechanics.  There are several experiments that demonstrate this including the double slit experiment where a particle is a wave and a particle at the same time. Or the superposition experiment where a wave is in two places at the same time.  There are event good applications of schrodinger’s cat in things like quantum computers.

Right, he was using it to back the Copenhagen Interpretation of Neils Bohr and Heisenberg.  In CI, 'where is the particle prior to my observation?', or 'is the cat alive?' are meaningless questions.  So, by showing the seemingly ridiculous consequences of actually asking these questions, he concluded that the only physically meaningful statements that can be made about a system are those made after the measurement.  Maybe it's a cop-out, but it's still the leading (and IMO best) interpretation.

Yes, but actual experiments have confirmed that this is actually how objects behave at the quantum scale.

The Schrodinger cat thought experiment was Schrodinger way of criticizing the Heisenberg uncertainty principle in which upon the observation of the two slit experiment, the observer determines the quantum state of photons (Either wave or particle) when an experiment was run to see a wave, you got a wave, when it was run to see if you had particles, you had particles. The principle became that you couldn't have one or the other until you observed it. Schrodinger cat is a critique of that.

The cat is just an analogy of wavefunction collapse. For macroscopic objects, the associated wavefunction is too small to detect, but for something the size of an electron, it is much larger, so the probabilistic nature dominates. Thus you can't know position without incurring uncertainty in momentum, etc. In effect, the particle could be anywhere. It may be more likely to be in some places than others, but you cannot determine something about it without losing information about something else.

The whole point of this thought experiment was to describe how ludicrous the entire idea of something existing in two possible states at once was.  The idea of Schrodinger's Cat was to point out just how ludicrous this theory was, as this theory was meant to describe the state of subatomic particles.  Schrodinger came along and used his cat in a box analogy to point out how stupid the idea was.  Schrodinger's Cat, missing the point since 1935.

This is just an analogy - the cat is really a subatomic particle, the bunker is an atom, and the gunpowder is... some thing that can affect the atom. So worrying about possibilities that apply to a cat in reality (such as finding out the state by a meow or other 'cheating') just aren't relevant to this example.

That's why it seems a weird thing to talk about - in real life we will know what happens due to the loud 'bang', for example. 

But in the subatomic world we really don't know.

My favorite explanation of this is that particles are somehow conscious, especially since new research is finding increasingly clear evidence that quantum states are fundamental to brain function. It's interesting how you can replace particles A, B, and C by human beings, and location 1, 2 and 3 by their behavior, and conscious human choice as the reason for not one definite situation, but several probable situations.

Subatomic particle A is surrounded by subatomic particle B and C. On the basis of B and C, A can be in place 1, 2, or 3. Obviously particle A is only at one place at a time, not three. We simply can't tell which place this is, so we describe it in terms of probability (thus place 1, 2 or 3). When we observe particle A to see where it is, we inadvertedly add particle D to the equation, adding location 4 to particle A's probable locations, thus influencing the outcome of the experiment.

Section 5 of Schrodinger's 1935 “cat” paper is titled “Are the Variables Really Blurred?” (In the original German: “Sind die Variablen wirklich verwaschen?”).  He pointedly described an absurd both-alive-and-also-dead cat, to show the absurdity of a “blurred” view of physical 'Reality.'
Schrodinger said that his Nobel-winning equation does *not* directly describe physical 'Reality' at every moment -- so there's *not* a blurred alive-and-dead cat.  This video got it all totally backward.
