@WastedGunner I urge you to pick up a textbook.  In 'quantum field theory', the 'observer' and the von-Neumann-style wave function 'collapse' simply don't exist.  Modern college-level and graduate-level Q.M. textbooks reflect the current understanding.

@OtherVerse My allusion to the Heisenberg's uncertainty relation was also not acute, since that principle requires taking two measurements in different spaces. I was not sure at how adept you were at theoretical physics and I was attempting to use a well-known example. I was merely describing the non-classical phenomenon of a wavefunction, In that you are describing a probability density, where you can only know with some certainty where a particle is. And you must observe it, collapsing the wf.

@OtherVerse You are right, the word analogy was perhaps not the best choice or words. It was a demonstration on wavefunction collapse. Its use after its introduction however has usually been used more as a point against quantum theory. However entanglement and wavefunctions are still prominent in quantum field theory. The information of interaction field theory is encapsulated in the S matrix built up from the quantum fields and is used to calculate the probability of scattering processes.

@WastedGunner Please read Schrodinger's 1935 paper.  Schrodinger's cat example was *not* an 'analogy' but rather a way to make an ontological point about his wave function, within the then-current 'measurement' scheme of von Neumann.  It doesn't hinge on Heisenberg's uncertainty relation, since only one measurement occurs.
Separately, modern 'quantum field theory' explains entanglement naturally in its space-occupying fields. No observer.  Find a textbook to see for yourself.

@OtherVerse In fact I just rewatched it, and as a physics student myself, it is quite the current understanding of physics. This in no way advocates its truth, merely that we have yet to come up with a satisfying explanation to quantum entanglement and the collapsing wavefunctions (or in other words, the ~seemingly~ random observations from uncertain quantum states.) :)

@OtherVerse I believe the author has a masters in theoretical physics. Merely attempting to bridge the gap from a scholar/student, to a layman.

the cat is a macroscopic analogy to how we ACTUALLY understand quantum mechanics. It was a thought experiment originally designed to demonstrate how absurd the idea is. But on the quantum level there is still no parallel to the superposition treatment of nature. In fact Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is a defining aspect of the quantum world.

@vandal2k6 This thought experiment is simply an interpretation of quantum mechanics applied to everyday objects and is used to highlight the absurdity of it. @apeman939 One of the restrictions of the experiment was that if the observer looked - then the cat will surely die. The quantum physics interpretation of the cat being dead or alive before it is observed is both states (both dead and alive at the same time). @AleifrLeifrson That is usually true, but a bit of an oversimplification. Usually, interaction with a macroscopic environment where everything is jiggling around will force quantum systems to settle into a definite state (this is the analogue of 'observing the cat' - it doesn't have to be a person, it is usually jiggling particles). 

However, this particular example is constructed so that the quantum events *will* have a macroscopic effect - the poison getting released or not.
But the cat wouldnt see the powder explode. it would be dead.

@ElectronXIII It was made to mock a certain interpretation of the descriptions that quantum mechanics makes. This video isn't supporting any interpretation either - it is simply using this simple example to explain the way that quantum mechanics describes things.

The way I have understood it is that these quantum events do not have any macroscopic effect.

@symbal777 Schrodinger's 1935 paper was cautioning physicists not to misinterpret the psi-function in his equation as a literal description of anything *physically* blurred in a mixture of states. (No blurred dead/alive cats at any time.)
He was instead telling them to see the psi-function's state-mixtures as a useful mathematical *abstraction* centered on clear eigenvalue measurement results: "Die psi-Funktion als Katalog der Erwartung." "The Psi-function as Expectation-catalog."

@OtherVerse It's also worth pointing out that in section four of that paper, he argues that we can't have a 'definite' model for representing reality either. He is essentially just saying that it's unsatisfying either way. He ultimately opts for putting things in terms of maximal states of information, which seems as good a way as any. But this doesn't conflict at all with what's in the video. It's tangential to it.

@OtherVerse The paper you mention is not about quantum mechanics. It is about the interpretation of quantum mechanics (or meta-quantum mechanics if you will). The video, on the other hand, just tells us how quantum mechanics describes the situation. It tells us this correctly. 

What should we make of the fact that quantum mechanics describes things this way? That is the question Schrodinger is discussing. It's a deep and interesting question, but it doesn't invalidate the video.

@AleifrLeifrson He understands it. The cat follows classical physics, but the gunpowder doesn't. Perhaps the gunpowder gets triggered by radioactive decay, which is governed by quantum rules. 

The thing is set up so that a quantum event has macroscopic effects - something that doesn't typically happen, due to air molecules bouncing around and disturbing the superposition, etc. But this thought experiment makes sense, and is meant to illustrate how bizarre qm's description of measurement is.

@maxim2themax Not so quick. The whole point is to explain an absurdity in how quantum mechanics describes things. And yes, it seems absurd. However, you can't dismiss it so quickly. Because for certain things that happen, this is the only way to describe them! For example, read about the two-slit experiment. Here's a video that explains it, starting about 10 minutes in:

You missed a key part of the experiment, why it "makes sense". The release of poison is determined by decay of a radioactive particle, which determines the death of the cat. Because "Quantum physics is weird", we cannot know if the particle decays or not until we observe it, until then the particle can be said to have both decayed, and not decayed. When we check the particle, we find out one has happened, this is called "collapse". So decay uncertainty implies uncertainty in if the cat lives.

No one really understands this video because it refers to quantum mechanics. Quantum-scale objects do not behave as things we can see with our eyes.  When we take a picture of a quantum-scale object, we will only be able to see one of its multiple states, because quantums are so funny they can actually have several different states at the same time (or, as the Schrödinger paradox puts it, both "dead" and "alive"). So the observer affects the observation.

However, when we place a sensor at the slits to detect which slit the photon passes through, the sensors in the back will pick up a very different pattern, two slits. Just the action of observation made the photons behave differently, as normal particles. Repeating this same test with entire atoms and even the buckey-ball showed the same results.
Actually, I was wrong to say two particles will be detected. The pattern on the sensor will actually be several slits, since the light behaves as a wave.

Light exhibits this feature actually. By sending a photon (light), through two slits, and using a sensor on the other side to detect the particle, the sensor will actually detect two particles, as if the photon passed through both slits. (Due to the wave-particle duality)

The point of this theory is to explain the concept of time and decision. The universe and the culmination of factors will decide the cat's fate, yes, but not all things are so simple. You could ask the question 'if a tree falls in the forest, and nothing is around to hear it, does it make a sound?'

@GeniusJibon We assume that we can't know whether the cat dies or not. Quantum Physics specifies then that it'll interact as being dead and alive.

A practical example would be shooting electrons through a double slit. Since we don't know through which slit the electron moves, it moves through both, interacts with itself and causes an interference pattern. But if we measure which slit the electron passes through, the interference pattern vanishes(it only goes through one slit).

This confused me too, until I looked it up and found out that quantum mechanics doesn't apply at this scale, but only at a very small subatomic scale. Schrodinger's cat was set up as a thought exercise to demonstrate how weird the physics of really small things is by using the CAT AS AN ANALOGY FOR REALLY, REALLY SMALL STUFF.  IT IS A HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE ANALOGY.
So, because the bunker has no fresh air supply, the cat will just suffocate and die. ;)

Although on a positive note, I think that the concept to take away from this thought experiment is "you never know what will be (because we are subjective) until you go an experience it." This concept has practicalities that are very important with mentation and emotionality.

Well, this is just wrong. The "unstable gunpowder" and "poison" initiators hide the essential quantum behavior. Schroedinger's Cat" is a thought experiment. There are plenty of quantum behaviors that don't translate exactly to "real-world" things like explosives or poisons because they deal with statistical fluctuations acting on single particles, whereas most of the real world is made up of (at the smallest level) at least hundreds, if not millions of atoms.

@CynicalCell Uncertainty principle. It's actually something that derives from the properties of waves; if you attempt to figure out the position of an atom, you naturally adjust it. Similarly, if you try to predict where it will go in the future, you will not know where it is now. There will always be something unknown about an atom, regardless of how much you try. In other words, it's a superposition of these states, through the wave-particle duality of an atom.

Without going into probability and advanced linear algebra, basically what happens is that you have a particle that is in a linear superposition of states. We do not know for certain what state the system is in, only a probabilistic outcome is possible. Once you make the measurement you disturb the system and it changes to the resulting eigenstate that you observed. Therefore if you preform the same measurement you will obtain whatever value you measured the first time with Prob = 1.

The major problem with schrodinger's cat is that it assumes that there are indeterminates in nature.  Is it really possible, for example, for a keg of gunpowder to have a 50% chance of exploding, or did it actually have a 100% chance of doing whatever it eventually did, and we just didn't know enough about it to determine what it would do beyond a 50% certainty. If you take the latter view, observation didn't force nature's hand.

@randyrocket 
There's a lot of evidence that the act of observation does alter reality (it doesn't have to be a living observer, as was not realized in Schrodinger's time).  In the words of John Wheeler:  "In the real world of quantum physics, no elementary phenomenon is a phenomenon until it is a recorded phenomenon."  Light that left a star millions of years ago can be recorded as either a particle or a wave, today - before then, what was it?  No time passed for the light, too.

@321ian Let suppose you have an atom, whose state is unknowable without affecting its state. In fact, it's actually in all of its states at once, a superposition, because of its wave/particle dual nature. But then, why does this happen? Why can an atom be at all states at once and why is it one of the few things in nature that can happen like this? Schrodinger's Cat is the thought experiment that tries to solve this.

@SirAvalord An atom's state is unmeasureable without changing the state itself, rending the measurement useless. So according to this thought experiment, an atom's state is a superposition of all states it could be in (because there's no way to know its actual state). This has a large number of applications, the most important being that we can overlap all of the atom's states to express it. Basically, this is important for anything that uses quantum physics.
@SirAvalord You don't get it, do you?

@BoredomBrat It's not really a theory so much as a "what-if" scenerio that actually happens, to an extent. See, an atom's state can't be measured without changing its state, because anything we measure with it will affect it. So, because of that, an atom is in a superposition of two states, like Schrodinger's Cat. This actually has a large and quantifiable effect on quantum physics and experiments, and is partly why we can apply wave properties of atomic particles.

@duhg599 But what he's really talking about is quantum physics. The cat is both alive and dead until we observe it, similar to the two-slit experiment in quantum physics, where an electron is in one of the slits, the other slit, both of the slits, neither of the slits, and all around - until we observe it, and it is forced to choose one of the probabilities. Yes, in reality, the cat would be either alive or dead before we check, but from a physicist's view it might as well be both before then.

This totally obscures the true nature of the "observer" in quantum mechanics.  The important thing is that every observation causes a change in what you are observing.  If you want to know the spin vector of an electron, you have to put it in a magnetic field. If it gives off light as it's spin vector aligns with the magnetic field, it was down. To mathematically show the big idea (Hopefully).

In quantum mechanics the state of a system is usually represented a set of state vectors, with the probability of measuring a given state as its amplitude squared, which in Dirac notation. 

|φ> =  1/√2|Alive> +1/√2|Dead>

The thing is when you make a measurement the state changes to the state that you just measured. So each subsequent measurement (in this case since the states are orthogonal) will always yield whatever state you first measured.

@Langotriel1 The theory of quantum mechanics says that the state of a system is not just representing some information (cat=dead or cat=alive). It actually represents represents the different observable states the system could be in (cat = sqrt(2)*(|dead>+|alive>)) and their probabilities of occuring. Observing the system forces it into one of these observable states. The cat is alive and dead until you observe what happens, then the cat will be forced into one of the observables.

This is the most frivolous experiment. Just because you are unaware of something does not mean that, that thing does not exist, or that a certain occurrence has not taken place. 

For example, if I flip a coin and then slap it down on the back side of one of my hands before either of us can see it, the upside of the coin is still either heads or tails. Not both. Furthermore, if I look which side is up but you don't, just because you are unaware of which side is up does not mean one isn't.

So here's the gist: an isolated probabilistic event cannot be predicted, and must be assumed to have happened all ways until the event has been interacted (de-isolated).  What's bizarre about quantum physics is that the event /does/ appear to happen all possible ways, unless an interaction interferes.
For clarity: It's interaction what entangles, not observation.
